timeline.title: A Brief History of American Journalism
timeline.subtitle: 1690–Present Day

events.title: Public Occurrences
events.text:
Public Domain


The first American newspaper ended in the arrest of the publisher in 1690.

events.title: Pennsylvania Gazette
events.text:
Public Domain


Benjamin Franklin circulated the most popular newspaper in the colonies in 1729.

events.title: Declaration of Independence & the First Amendment
events.text:
Public Domain


In 1776, a Boston newspaper ran a story about the first battle of the American Revolution.

events.title: Declaration of Independence & the First Amendment
events.text:
Public Domain


The same year, several newspapers ran the complete Declaration of Independence, sharing the document with the colonies.

events.title: Cherokee Phoenix
events.text:
Public Domain


In the early 1800s, many more daily newspapers and regular magazines came out, including some in other languages.

events.title: New York Herald & the Tribune
events.text:
Public Domain


By 1835, newspaper sections focusing on sports and other features appeared. Shortly after, Horace Greeley became an influential news editor with the New York Tribune.

events.title: New York Times
events.text:
Public Domain


The New York Times, still one of the most popular newspapers today, was founded in 1851.

events.title: Photographers and Reporters
events.text:
Public Domain


In the mid to late 1800s, telegraphs and railroads helped reporters send news across long distances. Photographers and reporters traveled to cover the Civil War.

events.title: William Randolph Hearst
events.text:
Public Domain


William Randolph Hearst began his career as a newspaper mogul in 1887.

events.title: Pulitzer Prize
events.text:
Public Domain


Publisher Joseph Pulitzer died in 1911, leaving funds to Columbia University to open a graduate school of journalism. He also left money to establish the Pulitzer Prize, which is still considered one of the highest awards a journalist can receive.

events.title: Radio
events.text:
© 2010 AP intmedia


It wasn’t until the 1920s that radio entered the scene, giving audiences a new option for gathering their news.

events.title: Citizen Kane
events.text:
© RKO/Turner Entertainment


Filmmaker and actor Orson Welles released a fictional exposé of the newspaper industry with his 1941 movie Citizen Kane. It depicted a negative characterization of William Randolph Hearst as the wealthy publisher, Kane.

events.title: Television
events.text:
© 2010 AP intmedia


The same decade, television news started, and films began showing short clips of news items before or after the shows.

events.title: All The President's Men
events.text:
© 2010 Simon & Schuster


In the 1970s, newspapers, radio, and television covered the Vietnam War. Bob Woodward and Carl Bernstein of the Washington Post met with an anonymous source, known to the public only as “Deep Throat,” to uncover the Nixon Watergate scandal.

events.title: Rupert Murdoch
events.text:
Public Domain


Rupert Murdoch began to build his media empire in 1973.

events.title: From Typewriters to Computers
events.text:
© 2010 AP intmedia


By the 1980s, many news organizations had moved from typewriters to computers.

events.title: The Internet
events.text: The Internet opened to commercial users in 1988.

events.title: Yahoo! and the Web
events.text:
© 2009 ASSOCIATED PRESS


In 1994, people were using the World Wide Web and it was receiving a lot of news coverage. Yahoo! opened.

events.title: Bloggings Beginnings
events.text: Blogging, once known as the online diary, started in 1997.

events.title: Citizen Journalism
events.text: With the introduction of the Internet, news sources found other avenues to deliver information to the public. Citizen journalism also began to rise in popularity, and the Internet search engine Google started up.

events.title: Y2K
events.text: Y2K was relatively uneventful. Free online classified ads at Craigslist grew with 30 million postings a month. Newspaper classified ad sales, an important source of revenue, became almost obsolete.

events.title: Social Media Begins
events.text: Facebook began collecting friends. Flickr shared its first photographs. Podcasting started.

events.title: YouTube and Internet News
events.text: The Huffington Post Internet news site mixed professional news, opinion reporting, and user-generated content. YouTube shared its first videos.

events.title: Twitter Begins
events.text: Twitter began tweeting in 140 characters or less.

events.title: Online News Becomes the Standard
events.text: The Internet is responsible for most Americans' news consumption. Two-thirds get some news online each day.

events.title: Internet Advertising
events.text: Internet advertising increased, while advertising in print and television decreased.

events.title: Digital Revolution
events.text:
The digital revolution means people are connected wherever they are. Half of American adults own a smartphone and a quarter have a tablet. This mobility increases news consumption, boosting journalism.


Source: University of North Carolina Pembroke
